metadata.titleEn: An evapotranspiration dataset based on upscaling eddy covariance observations over the temperate semi-arid grassland of China (1982-2015)
metadata.description: As an important part of global semi-arid grassland, adequately understanding the spatio-temporal variability of evapotranspiration (ET) over the temperate semi-arid grassland of China (TSGC) could advance our understanding of climate, hydrological and ecological processes over global semi-arid areas. Based on the largest number of in-situ ET measurements (13 flux towers) within the TSGC, we applied the support vector regression method to develop a high-quality ET dataset at 1 km spatial resolution and 8-day timescale for the TSGC from 1982 to 2015. The model performed well in validation against flux tower‐measured data and comparison with water-balance derived ET.
metadata.instructions:
Datasets are organized in netcdf files. There is one netcdf file per year, and they are stored as a 3D array with dimensions 2093 x 1123 x 46 (46 is the number of 8-day per year). Therefore, the first cell corresponds to the 1st 8-day of the corresponding year, and it is centred at latitude 35.5176 and longitude 103.4511. ‘DATA’ is 8-day ET [mm/8d]. Missing values in the files are masked with NaN.
See the file “Coverage_The temperate semi-arid grassland of China.tif” for study region.

background: Semi-arid areas account for about 15% of global land area, which feeds about 14% of the global population. It’s a critical region for Earth’s climate due to the vast area, high sensitivity to global warming, significant feedbacks on the global climate system, and the fragile eco-environment to anthropogenic disturbances. The temperate semi-arid grassland of China (TSGC) constitutes an integral part of the Mongolian Plateau and Eurasian semi-arid steppe ecosystem. Evapotranspiration (ET) is the dominated component (i.e., 80-90% of precipitation) of the hydrologic cycle over the arid and semi-arid regions. The change in water balance (WB, the sum of the total runoff and the change in the total terrestrial water storage, defined as precipitation-ET) is also a key aspect of the water cycle and is considered as the primary indicator of water availability. However, accurately estimating ET remains challenging in the arid and semi-arid areas where the two main types of models for ET estimation (i.e., process-based and remote sensing-based ET model) generally performed worse than in humid areas. The poor performance of process-based ET models in arid and semi-arid ecosystems is mainly because they require extensive and accurate parameterizations of land surface factors, which are highly variable in these regions. The challenges for remote sensing-based ET models in this region include low vegetation signal-to-noise ratios, high spatial heterogeneity from plot to regional scales, and irregular growing seasons due to unpredictable seasonal rainfall and frequent periods of drought. Machine learning (or data-driven) approaches have been identified as the most suitable approach for ET estimation, and was applied to upscale the eddy-covariance (EC) flux tower measurements from site to region scale using remote sensing, meteorological reanalysis, and land cover data.
research objective: In this study, we improved the ET estimates over the TSGC by a machine learning model driven by the largest number of in-situ ET measurements (13 flux towers) in this region till now. Based on the estimated regional ET dataset, we aim to (1) assess the magnitude, inter-annual variability, and spatial changes in ET and WB over the TSGC during 1982-2015, (2) identify the drivers of ET and WB trends, and (3) compare the ET dataset of this study with four commonly used global ET datasets.
challenges: However, accurately estimating ET remains challenging in the arid and semi-arid areas where the two main types of models for ET estimation (i.e., process-based and remote sensing-based ET model) generally performed worse than in humid areas. The poor performance of process-based ET models in arid and semi-arid ecosystems is mainly because they require extensive and accurate parameterizations of land surface factors, which are highly variable in these regions. The challenges for remote sensing-based ET models in this region include low vegetation signal-to-noise ratios, high spatial heterogeneity from plot to regional scales, and irregular growing seasons due to unpredictable seasonal rainfall and frequent periods of drought. These challenges encountered by the two types of ET models largely reduce the accuracy of ET estimation.
methods: We applied the support vector regression (SVR) method to develop a high-quality ET dataset for the TSGC from 1982 to 2015.
dataset: We selected 13 flux sites within the TSGC, the underlying surfaces of which were either typical steppe or sandy grassland. The observation items included precipitation (Prec), air temperature (Ta), wind speed (Ws), relative humidity (RH), net radiation (Rn), incoming longwave radiation (Lrad), incoming shortwave radiation (Srad), and latent heat flux (LE). After the above processing, we finally obtained a total of 1012 sets of 8-day LE data in which 7 flux sites of typical steppe and 6 flux sites of sandy grassland provided 617 and 395 sets of 8-day LE data, respectively.
findings: The comparison at multi-year average scale (Fig. 11) showed that the R2 of ETSVR and ETwb was 0.30 and the relative error was 10.0%. The ETSVR showed similar inter-annual variability with ETwb (the average R2 was 0.55), while the range of inter-annual variability in ETwb is much higher than that of ETSVR. Overall, although the SVR-ET model was not constrained by water balance, the predicted ET coincided with the magnitude and variability of the ET estimation based on the catchment water balance equation.

Definition.Question: What is the role of machine learning, specifically support vector regression, in the estimation of evapotranspiration?
Definition.Answer: Machine learning, particularly support vector regression (SVR), plays a significant role in estimating evapotranspiration by providing a data-driven approach that can handle the challenges associated with traditional models. SVR helps in developing high-quality datasets by upscaling flux tower measurements using remote sensing, meteorological reanalysis, and land cover data, thereby improving accuracy over arid and semi-arid regions where other models may perform poorly.

Comparison.Question: How does the use of machine learning, specifically support vector regression, for estimating evapotranspiration in temperate semi-arid grasslands compare to traditional process-based and remote sensing-based models?
Comparison.Answer: Machine learning approaches, like support vector regression, have been identified as more suitable for estimating evapotranspiration in arid and semi-arid areas compared to traditional process-based and remote sensing-based models. This is because process-based models require extensive and accurate parameterizations of land surface factors, which are variable in these regions, and remote sensing-based models face challenges such as low vegetation signal-to-noise ratios and high spatial heterogeneity.

Comparison.Question: In terms of data collection for evapotranspiration estimation, how does the spatial and temporal resolution of flux tower data compare to the resolution achieved through the integration of remote sensing data?
Comparison.Answer: Flux tower data provide high-resolution local measurements, but when integrated with remote sensing and meteorological reanalysis data, the spatial resolution can be extended to 1km and temporal resolution to 8-day intervals, as demonstrated in the dataset covering 1982-2015. This integration allows for regional scale analysis which is not possible with flux tower data alone.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences in the challenges faced by process-based and remote sensing-based models in estimating evapotranspiration in arid and semi-arid regions?
Comparison.Answer: Both process-based and remote sensing-based models face challenges in arid and semi-arid regions. Process-based models struggle due to the need for extensive and accurate parameterizations of highly variable land surface factors. Remote sensing-based models encounter issues such as low vegetation signal-to-noise ratios, high spatial heterogeneity, and irregular growing seasons. Both types of models generally perform worse in these regions than in humid areas.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the challenges in data collection methods for estimating evapotranspiration in semi-arid regions, given the variability in land surface factors and the limitations of existing models?
Interpretation.Answer: The challenges in accurately estimating evapotranspiration in semi-arid regions stem from the high variability in land surface factors, which make extensive and precise parameterizations necessary. Existing models, both process-based and remote sensing-based, struggle due to these variations and additional issues like low vegetation signal-to-noise ratios, high spatial heterogeneity, and irregular growing seasons. These factors collectively reduce the accuracy of evapotranspiration estimation.

Interpretation.Question: What implications does the reliance on flux tower measurements have for developing evapotranspiration datasets, and how can these data be effectively scaled to regional levels?
Interpretation.Answer: Flux tower measurements provide critical in-situ data that can be upscaled to regional levels using machine learning techniques. By integrating these localized observations with broader datasets such as remote sensing and meteorological reanalysis, researchers can develop comprehensive evapotranspiration datasets that reflect regional dynamics more accurately, addressing the spatial heterogeneity present in semi-arid ecosystems.

Goal Orientation.Answer: The key objectives of utilizing support vector regression in creating a high-quality evapotranspiration dataset for temperate semi-arid grasslands include assessing the magnitude, inter-annual variability, and spatial changes in ET and water balance, identifying drivers of ET trends, and comparing the dataset with other global ET datasets.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it necessary to include a variety of observation items like precipitation, air temperature, and radiation in data collection for evapotranspiration studies?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Including a variety of observation items like precipitation, air temperature, and radiation in data collection for evapotranspiration studies is necessary due to the complex nature of ET processes, which are influenced by multiple environmental factors. This comprehensive approach aids in developing accurate models that can better predict ET in semi-arid regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is remote sensing data integrated with meteorological and land cover data to improve evapotranspiration estimates in semi-arid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Remote sensing data is integrated with meteorological reanalysis and land cover data to upscale eddy-covariance flux tower measurements. Machine learning models, specifically support vector regression, are applied to develop a high-quality evapotranspiration dataset. This integration allows for capturing spatial and temporal variability in evapotranspiration beyond the flux tower locations, improving the regional accuracy of the estimates.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in validating a machine learning-based evapotranspiration dataset against observed data and water balance models?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedural steps for validating a machine learning-based evapotranspiration dataset include comparing the predicted evapotranspiration values with observed data from multiple flux sites and with estimates derived from catchment water balance models. Performance metrics such as R2 and relative error are used to assess the model's accuracy, while also examining the inter-annual variability and magnitude of evapotranspiration in comparison to water balance-based estimates to ensure consistency and reliability.

Enablement.Question: What conditions are necessary to ensure the accuracy of evapotranspiration models in semi-arid grasslands, and how do they influence data collection and processing?
Enablement.Answer: Ensuring the accuracy of evapotranspiration models in semi-arid grasslands requires conditions such as extensive and accurate parameterizations of land surface factors, sufficient in-situ measurements from multiple flux towers, and the integration of remote sensing and meteorological data. These conditions influence data collection and processing by demanding robust and adaptive methods to handle low vegetation signal-to-noise ratios and irregular growing seasons.

Enablement.Question: In what ways do the integration of remote sensing data and meteorological reanalysis enhance the understanding of evapotranspiration and water balance dynamics in semi-arid regions?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of remote sensing data and meteorological reanalysis enhances the understanding of evapotranspiration and water balance dynamics by providing comprehensive spatial and temporal coverage, allowing for the assessment of inter-annual variability, spatial changes, and the identification of drivers of trends in these processes across large and heterogeneous areas like semi-arid regions.

Expectation.Answer: The challenges for remote sensing-based ET models in semi-arid regions include low vegetation signal-to-noise ratios, high spatial heterogeneity from plot to regional scales, and irregular growing seasons due to unpredictable seasonal rainfall and frequent periods of drought.

Expectation.Answer: Machine learning approaches have been identified as the most suitable for ET estimation in arid and semi-arid areas because traditional process-based models require extensive and accurate parameterizations of land surface factors, which are highly variable, and remote sensing-based models face challenges such as low vegetation signal-to-noise ratios and high spatial heterogeneity.

Judgmental.Question: How do you evaluate the effectiveness of using machine learning models, such as support vector regression, for enhancing evapotranspiration estimation in semi-arid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Machine learning models like support vector regression have been identified as suitable for enhancing evapotranspiration estimation because they can upscale eddy-covariance flux tower measurements using various data sources like remote sensing, meteorological reanalysis, and land cover data. These models address the challenges faced by process-based and remote sensing-based models in semi-arid regions, such as variability in land surface factors and high spatial heterogeneity.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the potential challenges in ensuring the quality and accuracy of data collected from multiple flux sites in semi-arid grasslands?
Judgmental.Answer: The potential challenges include low vegetation signal-to-noise ratios, high spatial heterogeneity from plot to regional scales, and irregular growing seasons due to unpredictable seasonal rainfall and frequent droughts. These factors can significantly reduce the accuracy of data collected from flux sites in semi-arid grasslands.

Judgmental.Question: What is your perspective on the adequacy of using 13 flux sites across temperate semi-arid grasslands for developing a comprehensive evapotranspiration dataset?
Judgmental.Answer: Using 13 flux sites provides extensive in-situ measurements which are crucial for developing a high-quality evapotranspiration dataset. These sites, covering typical steppe and sandy grassland, allow for the collection of diverse data sets, such as precipitation, temperature, wind speed, and latent heat flux, enabling a robust evapotranspiration estimation through machine learning models.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the main methods used for collecting evapotranspiration data in temperate semi-arid grasslands and discuss their potential limitations.
Request/Directive.Answer: The main methods for collecting evapotranspiration data include eddy-covariance (EC) flux tower measurements, remote sensing data, and meteorological reanalysis. The limitations include the need for extensive parameterizations in process-based models, low vegetation signal-to-noise ratios, high spatial heterogeneity, and irregular growing seasons, which challenge remote sensing-based models.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced in accurately estimating evapotranspiration in arid and semi-arid regions and suggest potential machine learning approaches to address these issues.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in estimating evapotranspiration in arid and semi-arid regions include the variability of land surface factors, low vegetation signal-to-noise ratios, and high spatial heterogeneity. Machine learning approaches, such as support vector regression (SVR), can address these issues by using a data-driven approach to upscale EC flux tower measurements combined with remote sensing and meteorological data.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify and describe potential datasets that could be used to enhance the understanding of spatial and temporal changes in evapotranspiration over the temperate semi-arid grasslands of China.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets include in-situ measurements from 13 flux sites, which cover different surfaces like typical steppe and sandy grassland, providing data on precipitation, air temperature, wind speed, relative humidity, net radiation, and latent heat flux. These datasets can be used to analyze spatial and temporal changes in evapotranspiration when combined with machine learning techniques.
